p: This replicon system was then used in high-throughput screening for specific anti-RSV drugs acting on the replication machinery of this virus. The small-molecule compound AZ-27 was found to inhibit transcription and replication initiation [79]. This finding was later confirmed using the minigenome system [80]. In 2014, Laganas et al. further screened the Astra Zeneca compound library in a high-throughput approach using the RSV replicon and identified three new lead compounds – nucleoside analogues and non-nucleoside inhibitors of the RSV RdRp [81]. In 2015 > 100 nucleoside analogue polymerase inhibitors were screened using the HeLa395-RV replicon cell line. Compound ALS-8176 was found to be a first-in-class small-molecule inhibitor of RSV replication, acting by chain termination during replication [82]. The compound was abandoned by Johnson & Johnson in March 2019 after Phase IIb trials [83].
